0.9% Sodium Chloride.description: Conventional amphotericin is not compatible with saline; precipitates/instability occur.
0.9% Sodium Chloride.nursingManagement: Infuse only in D5W through a dedicated line; do not Y-site with saline-based infusions.

D5W (5% Dextrose).description: Amphotericin is formulated for dextrose solutions.
D5W (5% Dextrose).nursingManagement: Use D5W as the sole diluent/side infusion if needed.

Liposomal Amphotericin B.description: Different formulations are not interchangeable and should not mix.
Liposomal Amphotericin B.nursingManagement: Use separate, dedicated lines for each formulation.

Vancomycin.description: Crystallization/precipitation can occur depending on concentration and pH.
Vancomycin.nursingManagement: Prefer separate lumen; if unavoidable, verify institutional compatibility table for specific concentrations.

0.9% Sodium Chloride.nursingManagement: Flush line before and after other drugs.

D5W (5% Dextrose).nursingManagement: Use standard line care; avoid mixing with high-pH/alkaline drugs.

Sodium Phosphate.description: Insoluble calcium phosphate forms rapidly on contact.
Sodium Phosphate.nursingManagement: Never co-infuse; use separate lines or flush thoroughly between.

Potassium Phosphate.description: Calcium and phosphate precipitate across a wide range of concentrations.
Potassium Phosphate.nursingManagement: Do not Y-site; separate line required.

Ceftriaxone.nursingManagement: Avoid any co-infusion; separate lines and time spacing with thorough flush.

Calcium Gluconate.nursingManagement: Do not co-administer via Y-site; ensure complete line separation and flushing.

Sodium Bicarbonate.description: Alkaline solutions reduce stability and may cause precipitation.

0.9% Sodium Chloride.description: Stable in normal saline at usual concentrations.

Ondansetron (IV).nursingManagement: Monitor site; flush between other incompatible agents.

Metoclopramide (IV).description: No clinically significant physical incompatibility reported.

Sodium Bicarbonate.description: Alkaline pH reduces stability of catecholamine/inotrope solutions.
Sodium Bicarbonate.nursingManagement: Do not mix; run via a separate lumen.

Heparin (IV infusion).description: Generally physically compatible at standard concentrations.
Heparin (IV infusion).nursingManagement: Use dedicated lumens when possible for titratable drips.

Sodium Bicarbonate.description: Alkaline solutions cause decomposition of dopamine.

0.9% Sodium Chloride.description: Stable in NS at standard ICU concentrations.
0.9% Sodium Chloride.nursingManagement: Prefer dedicated lumen for vasoactive medications.

Phenytoin (IV).description: High pH phenytoin solution is incompatible with many drugs including furosemide.
Phenytoin (IV).nursingManagement: Do not Y-site; use separate line or flush very thoroughly with NS.

D5W (5% Dextrose).description: Note for phenytoin: precipitates in dextrose solutions; NS only.
D5W (5% Dextrose).nursingManagement: Keep furosemide separate when phenytoin is running; follow diluent rules.

0.9% Sodium Chloride.description: Furosemide is stable in NS at usual concentrations.

Calcium Gluconate.nursingManagement: Do not co-infuse; flush line before/after heparin.

Sodium Phosphate.description: Generally stable when adequately diluted, but monitor for cloudiness.
Sodium Phosphate.nursingManagement: Use separate lumen if any doubt; inspect line for particulates.

Dobutamine.description: No significant precipitation at typical ICU concentrations.
Dobutamine.nursingManagement: Prefer dedicated lumen for titration clarity.

Ondansetron (IV).description: No physical incompatibility at standard doses.

Metoclopramide (IV).nursingManagement: Monitor site and tubing for haze/precipitate.

Dextrose solutions.description: Common ICU practice to Y-site with D10W/D20W for glycemic management.
Dextrose solutions.nursingManagement: Label lines clearly; frequent glucose checks.

Potassium Chloride (IV infusion).description: Often co-administered during hyperkalemia management; physical compatibility acceptable.
Potassium Chloride (IV infusion).nursingManagement: Use cardiac monitoring; follow local hyperkalemia protocol.

Propofol.description: Both are lipid emulsions; many policies allow Y-site, others prefer separation.
Propofol.nursingManagement: Follow institutional policy; dedicate lumen if possible to avoid confusion.

Most aqueous IV meds.description: Physical compatibility varies widely and may be concentration-dependent.
Most aqueous IV meds.nursingManagement: Prefer separate line for lipids; check local compatibility charts before Y-siting.

Aminophylline/Theophylline (IV).description: Reports of haze/precipitation depending on concentrations and vehicles.

0.9% Sodium Chloride.description: Stable in NS at typical concentrations.

Calcium Gluconate.description: Risk of precipitation and opposing ionic effects.
Calcium Gluconate.nursingManagement: Infuse via separate lumen; flush well if switching.

Potassium Chloride (IV).description: Often co-administered in ICU; generally no precipitation.
Potassium Chloride (IV).nursingManagement: Monitor ECG and electrolytes during concurrent replacement.

0.9% Sodium Chloride.description: Stable in NS at usual concentrations.

Vancomycin.description: Compatibility depends on concentration and formulation.
Vancomycin.nursingManagement: Prefer separate lumen; verify local compatibility tables.

Propofol.description: No precipitation expected; both CNS depressants (clinical, not physical).
Propofol.nursingManagement: If sharing lumen, ensure line clarity and appropriate monitoring.

Fentanyl (IV infusion).nursingManagement: Label lines; titrate independently where possible.

Sodium Bicarbonate.nursingManagement: Use separate lumen; do not Y-site.

0.9% Sodium Chloride.description: Stable in NS for carrier infusions.
0.9% Sodium Chloride.nursingManagement: Prefer a dedicated central lumen for vasoactive drips.

Metoclopramide (IV).nursingManagement: Inspect line for cloudiness if multi-drug Y-siting.

D5W (5% Dextrose).description: Precipitates in dextrose; NS is required.
D5W (5% Dextrose).nursingManagement: Use NS only; dedicated line preferred.

0.9% Sodium Chloride.nursingManagement: Avoid co-infusion with other meds; flush line before/after.

Furosemide (IV).description: pH-related precipitation with other alkaline drugs.
Furosemide (IV).nursingManagement: Do not Y-site; separate line mandatory.

Vancomycin (IV).description: Physical compatibility depends on concentrations/vehicles; reports vary.
Vancomycin (IV).nursingManagement: Prefer separate lumens; check local compatibility references for exact strengths.

0.9% Sodium Chloride.description: Stable in NS at usual concentrations.

Insulin Regular (IV).description: Used together in hyperkalemia protocols (physical compatibility acceptable).
Insulin Regular (IV).nursingManagement: Follow hyperkalemia protocol; label lines clearly.

Lipid Emulsion 20%.description: Both lipid emulsions; many institutions allow Y-site but policies differ.
Lipid Emulsion 20%.nursingManagement: Follow hospital policy; separate line preferred for clarity.

Most aqueous IV meds.description: Emulsion may not be compatible with all aqueous drugs.
Most aqueous IV meds.nursingManagement: Avoid mixing with other meds unless verified compatible.

Noradrenaline/Dopamine/Dobutamine.description: Alkaline pH degrades catecholamines and some inotropes.

Calcium Gluconate.nursingManagement: Avoid mixing; separate line and thorough flush if sequential.

Phenytoin (IV).nursingManagement: Do not Y-site; NS-only line for phenytoin.

Calcium Gluconate.nursingManagement: Never Y-site with calcium; separate line.

Heparin (IV infusion).nursingManagement: Observe for haze/particles; prefer separate lumen if available.

Most IV medications.description: Compatibility depends on TPN composition (amino acids, lipids, electrolytes).
Most IV medications.nursingManagement: Best practice is a dedicated central lumen; consult pharmacy/compatibility charts before any Y-site.

Lipid Emulsion 20%.description: Often co-infused as part of TPN or piggybacked per protocol.
Lipid Emulsion 20%.nursingManagement: Follow institutional TPN policy; use TPN-designated lumen.

Acyclovir (IV).nursingManagement: Prefer separate lumen; verify local tables if unavoidable.

Piperacillin–Tazobactam (IV).description: Reports vary; some concentrations are physically compatible, others not.
Piperacillin–Tazobactam (IV).nursingManagement: Use separate lines for reliability; check local compatibility chart.

0.9% Sodium Chloride.description: Stable in NS at typical concentrations.
